I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant to 

1. 
the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for the Mid-Level Skills Training Project.1 
 
2. 
The  proposed  project  will  assist  the  Government  of  Timor-Leste  in  introducing  and 
implementing  mid-level  skills  training  in  construction  and  automotive  trades  by  strengthening 
selected public and private training providers. The project will build on existing training programs 
and  facilities  which  have  a  proven  record  of  delivering  quality  skills  training  at  basic  levels.  By 
filling skills gaps in the current system of technical and vocational education and training (TVET), 
the  project  will  help  the  government  develop  a  skilled  workforce  and  improve  employment 
opportunities for men and women in Timor-Leste. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
The economy of Timor-Leste has been growing strongly, averaging annual growth of more 
than  10%  since  2007.  Timor-Leste’s  Strategic  Development  Plan  (SDP)  2011–2030  aims  to 
sustain double-digit economic growth, with a vision of building a modern, diversified economy by 
2030  focusing  on  high-quality  infrastructure  and  the  petroleum  sector  as  a  significant  industrial 
base.2 The  SDP  points  to  the  shortage  of  skilled  human  resources  as  a  critical  challenge  in 
achieving  this  vision  and,  in  response,  emphasizes  human  capital  investment,  particularly  job 
skills development, as a key strategy in coming years. 
 
4. 
The country’s population has been growing rapidly, averaging 2.4% growth in 2004–2010, 
and 52% of the nation’s population of 1.1 million is under the age of 20.3 Providing a large young 
population with knowledge and skills relevant for the rapidly developing economy and absorbing 
them into the labor force pose key challenges. The youth unemployment rate (among 15–29 year 
olds) is 19% nationally and 27% in urban areas. Underemployment is also extensive, with many 
young  people  absorbed  in  the  agriculture  sector  at  low  rates  of  productivity.  Despite  the 
abundance of unemployed and underemployed youth, the fast-growing economy is faced with a 
shortage  of  practically  skilled  Timorese  workers  and  relies  instead  on  considerable  numbers  of 
foreign  workers.  
 
5. 
The government’s plan to accelerate infrastructure development in areas  such as roads, 
building  construction,  water  supply,  and  energy  is  driving  demand  for  skilled  workers  in 
construction  trades.  With  the  rapid  expansion  of  construction  activities,  the  use  of  construction 
equipment, automobiles, and other transport services is rising rapidly, as is the demand for skilled 
mechanics.  Yet  few  Timorese  workers  have  technical  skills  that  can  support  rapid  infrastructure 
expansion.  According  to  the  2010  labor  force  survey,  about  13,000  persons  aged  15  and  older 
reported  working  in  construction  industries. 4  Only  3,000  of  these  workers  had  completed 
secondary, technical, or vocational education, and most of them were likely to work as semiskilled 
or unskilled workers. While there are no precise data on foreign skilled workers, a 2008 survey of 
enterprises  and  recent  field  studies  indicate  that  foreign  workers  fill  key  skilled  positions  in 

                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  Government of Timor-Leste. 2011. Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan 2011–2030. Dili (July). 
3  National  Statistics  Directorate  and  United  Nations  Population  Fund.  2011.  Timor-Leste  Population  and  Housing 

Census 2010. Social and Economic Characteristics. Volume 3. Dili. 

4  Secretariat of State for Vocational Training and Employment (SEFOPE) and National Statistics Directorate. 2010. Timor-

Leste Labor Force Survey 2010. Dili. 

 construction  and  auto-mechanical  fields. 5  Jobs  typically  filled  by  foreign  workers  included 
engineers and skilled positions such as plumbers, electricians, masons, welders, and mechanics. 
 
6. 
The TVET subsector in Timor-Leste consists of technical high schools under the Ministry 
of Education (MOE), and post-school vocational training providers overseen by the Secretariat of 
State  for  Vocational  Training  and  Employment  (SEFOPE).6 The  majority  of  vocational  training 
providers  are  supported  by  nongovernment  organizations,  church  institutions,  or  international 
donors.  Skills  training  programs  range  from  basic  life  skills  to  specific  occupational  skills.  Many 
vocational  training  programs,  however,  fall  short  in  preparing  trainees  with  skills  required  in  the 
labor  market  due  to  (i)  their  focus  on  remedial  courses  to  raise  basic  literacy  and  numeracy 
among  trainees,  (ii)  the  programs’  weak  links  to  the  labor  market,  (iii)  a  lack  of  standard 
qualifications for training institutions, and (iv) a lack of qualified teachers. Many training courses 
tend  to  be  supply  driven  or  in  low-cost  areas  such  as  business  administration  and  tourism,  with 
poor links to the needs of the local labor market. 
 
7. 
Quality  assurance  and  more  demand-driven  training  standards  have  recently  been 
adopted in the TVET subsector with support from development partners. To develop competency 
standards  based  on  industry  inputs  and  to  accredit  vocational  training  providers,  the  National 
Labor  Force  Development  Institute  (INDMO)  was  established  in  2008  as  an  autonomous 
regulatory  agency  under  the  auspices  of  SEFOPE.  Industry  subcommissions  have  been 
organized  to  advise  INDMO  on  competency  standards  and  qualifications  within  their  particular 
industry. For regulation and accreditation of post-secondary educational institutions, the National 
Agency for Academic Assessment and Accreditation (ANAAA)  was established under the  MOE. 
The  work  by  the  ANAAA  and  INDMO  formed  the  basis  of  the  national  qualification  framework 
(NQF), which was approved in April 2011. INDMO is responsible for regulating qualification levels 
1–4 of vocational training and foundation courses, while the ANAAA is responsible for qualification 
levels 5–10 in higher education.7 
 
The  most  recent  review  of  TVET  outcomes  by  SEFOPE  indicates  that  approximately 
8. 
1,900  trainees  completed  vocational  training  courses  in  2009  across  four  technical  areas—
administration and finance, tourism and hospitality, construction and mechanics, and agriculture.8 
Females  made  up  about  40%  of  these  trainees,  mostly  concentrated  in  administration,  finance, 
tourism,  and  hospitality.  About  32%  of  trainees  were  trained  in  construction  and  mechanical 
trades.  The  review  identified  15–18  providers  as  delivering  quality  training  across  a  range  of 
industry  areas,  but  mostly  at  basic  qualification  levels. While  there  is  an  increasing  demand  for 
mid-level  technical  workers  (levels  2–4),  particularly  in  construction  and  automotive  trades,  no 
vocational  training  provider  is  yet  to  provide  mid-level  skills  training  and  only  a  few  training 
providers have the capacity to deliver training at higher than basic levels. 
 
9. 
The project aims to help fill the gap in mid-level skills training (levels 2–4) in construction 
and  automotive  trades  by  targeting  and  upgrading  the  strongest  training  providers  to  deliver 

                                                
5  Richard  Curtain.  2009.  Skills  in  Demand:  Identifying  the  Skill  Needs  of  Enterprises  in  Construction  and  Hospitality  in 
Timor-Leste. Final draft for comment. Field studies on automotive repair shops and construction companies in Dili were 
carried out during project preparation. 

6  Official acronyms for government agencies are Portuguese acronyms. 
7  For qualification levels 1–4 under the NQF, a formal certificate is awarded when a person demonstrates the skills and 
knowledge specified in the industry competency standards, usually acquired through vocational training providers or on 
the job  training. Level 1 skills generally correspond to  workers being able to undertake  well-defined tasks in their skill 
area; at level 2 workers are able to perform a broader range of tasks in their skill area; level 3 workers are highly skilled 
technicians in their fields; and level 4 workers are supervisors. Qualification levels 5–10 represent diplomas and degrees 
from higher educational institutions, ranging from polytechnic diplomas to university doctorate degrees. 

8  SEFOPE. 2011. Review of 2009 TVET Training Outcomes. Dili. 

2 

 

 training  at  higher  than  basic  levels.  Given  past  and  ongoing  assistance  to  basic  education  and 
basic  skills  training  by  other  development  partners,  the  project  will  focus  its  support  on  specific 
mid-level  vocational  skills  training  through  SEFOPE.  To  implement  mid-level  skills  training,  the 
project  will  support  the  development  of  competency-based  training  standards  and  improve  the 
quality of teaching staff. It will also facilitate the role of the private sector and strengthen the labor 
market  information  system  (LMIS)  to  build  demand-driven  skills  training  that  is  relevant  and 
responsive to the needs of the expanding Timorese economy. 
 
The project is aligned with Timor-Leste’s SDP and its focus on accelerated infrastructure 
10. 
and  capacity  development.  The  project  is  the  first  major  step  in  the  engagement  by  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  in  TVET  in  Timor-Leste,  in  accordance  with  the  country  partnership 
strategy (CPS) 2011–2015 and country operations business plan 2011–2013.9 As indicated in the 
CPS,  ADB’s  extensive  experience  in  TVET  will  assist  the  government  in  addressing  skills 
shortages in infrastructure and other areas of the economy. 
 
11. 
The  project  is  also  harmonized  with  assistance  provided  by  other  development  partners. 
The Australian Agency for International Development and the International Labor Organization are 
major  partners  in  the  TVET  subsector.  Their  support  to  the  Youth  Employment  Promotion 
Program  since  2008  led  to  the  establishment  of  INDMO  and  the  NQF.  Other  development 
partners in TVET include the European Commission, the Government of Brazil, and the Spanish 
International Cooperation. The project builds on previous and ongoing support in TVET and will be 
implemented in close cooperation with these development partners. 
 
B. 
 
12. 
The  project  will  contribute  to  the  development  of  a  skilled  workforce  in  Timor-Leste  with 
improved  quality  and  higher  levels  of  vocational  training.  The  project’s  outcome  will  be  an 
enhanced TVET system with mid-level skills training (levels 2–4) that is relevant and responsive to 
labor market needs. 
 
C. 
 
The  project  will  deliver  five  outputs:  (i)  mid-level  skills  training  provision,  (ii)  technical 
13. 
teacher  training,  (iii)  enhanced  labor  market  linkages  of  TVET,  (iv)  strengthened  SEFOPE 
financing and support for TVET, and (v) project implementation and management. 
 

Impact and Outcome 

Outputs 

1. 

Mid-Level Skills Training Provision 

 
14. 
This output will support the provision of training at certificate levels 2–4 in construction and 
automotive  skills  by  (i)  developing  national  skills  standards  and  curricula,  (ii)  improving  technical 
skills of teachers, and (iii) upgrading facilities and equipment of selected training providers to deliver 
competency-based training. 
 
15. 
Development  of  industry-based  training  standards  and  curriculum. INDMO has been 
developing competency-based skills standards for levels 1–2 in construction and automotive skills 
based  on  industry  inputs  and  the  established  procedures  of  the  NQF.  The  project  will  support 
INDMO  to  further  develop  level  3–4  skills  standards,  including  modular  programs.  Curricula  and 
learning  materials  will  be  produced  by  adapting  internationally  available  materials  according  to 
Timor-Leste requirements. 

                                                
9  ADB. 2011. Country Partnership Strategy: Timor-Leste, 2011–2015. Manila; ADB. 2011. Country Operations Business 

Plan: Timor-Leste, 2011–2013. Manila.  

3 

 

 Upgrading  facilities  and  equipment  of  public  training  provider. The Tibar Training 
16. 
Center (Tibar) is one of two public training providers and is recognized by INDMO as delivering 
quality  basic  skills  training  in  construction  trades  (mainly  carpentry,  plumbing,  electrical, 
masonry, and solar energy).10 The project will finance the upgrading of facilities and equipment 
at  Tibar  to  deliver  competency-based  training  at  levels  2–4,  and  the  construction  of  dormitory 
facilities to expand access by students from remote areas and by women. The dormitory facility 
will also be used to accommodate teachers participating in technical teacher training programs 
(see output 2). 
 
Upgrading  facilities  and  equipment  of  private  training  providers.  The  project  will 
17. 
support two registered private (nongovernment) training providers—Dili Institute of Technology (DIT) 
Baucau and Don Bosco at Comoro—with facility and equipment upgrades to deliver mid-level skills 
training  in  the  project’s  priority  skill  areas. 11  They  will  be  required  to  enter  into  a  partnership 
agreement  with  SEFOPE  to  take  part  in  the  project.12 The  agreement  will  specify  the  scope  of 
assistance  for  each  training  provider  and  outline  the  rights  and  obligations  of  SEFOPE  and  the 
training  providers.  Obligations  of  training  providers  will  include  commitments  to  train  specified 
numbers  of  trainees  in  mid-level  skills  programs,  and  to  operate  and  maintain  upgraded  facilities 
and equipment. The agreements will ensure that support provided to the private training providers is 
passed  to  trainees  through  the  provision  of  quality  training  at  a  reduced  cost.  A  long-term  plan 
ensuring the continued delivery of mid-level skills training by these providers will also be developed 
during project implementation.13  
 

2. 

Technical Teacher Training 

 
This  output  will  improve  the  technical  and  pedagogical  capacity  of  teachers  from 
18. 
participating  training  providers  to  ensure  the  delivery  of  level  2–4  training  in  construction  and 
automotive trades. The project will help SEFOPE establish a new vocational training development 
center (VTDC), deliver  in-service training for TVET teaching staff, and develop  long-term plans to 
improve the skills of TVET teaching staff.  
 
19. 
Establishing a vocational training development center. A new VTDC will be established 
at  an  existing  facility  at  Tibar  with  appropriate  equipment  and  staff  to  provide  in-service  training 
programs for TVET technical teaching staff. The project will also support the development of a long-
term  plan  for TVET  teacher  training  programs,  and  an  institutional  plan  for  the  VTDC  outlining  its 
financing mechanism and sustainability.  
 
Training  of  trainers.  Intensive  in-service  training  at  the  VTDC  will  be  provided  by 
20. 
international trainers to TVET teaching staff to upgrade training skills in construction and automotive 
trades  according  to  approved  certification  standards.  Technical  training  will  be  combined  with  the 
existing  pedagogical  training  and  training  in  relevant  industry  settings,  which  will  be  offered  as 

                                                
10 Another  public  institution—the  Senai  Training  Center—was  established  with  support  from  the  Government  of 
Brazil, which continues to fund operational expenses except for salaries for trainers.  Since the Senai Center intends to 
continue training based on Brazilian certificate standards, it declined to be included in the project. 

11 The criteria for selecting private training providers for project support are described in the Selection Criteria and Profiles of 
Project Training Centers (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). There are currently only four private 
vocational  training  providers  that  deliver  basic-level  training  in  construction  and  automotive  skills  outside  the  formal 
educational  system.  Of  these  four  training  providers,  two  did  not  satisfy  selection  criteria,  and  hence  only  the  two 
remaining private training providers are included for project support. 

12 The  guidelines  on  the  preparation  of  the  proposed  partnership  agreement  are  in  the  Project  Administration  Manual 

(accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

13 The long-term plan to be developed will consider public–private partnership frameworks, if appropriate. 

4 

 

 modular programs. Teachers from the project’s three training providers will form a cadre of master 
trainers capable of passing on their skills to other technical teachers.  
 

3. 

Enhancing Labor Market Linkages of Technical and Vocational Education 
and Training 

 
21. 
Poor perceptions of TVET and lack of information about related career opportunities deter 
many young people from developing skills relevant to labor market needs. This output will support 
SEFOPE to (i) expand its TVET promotion activities and job counseling services, (ii) facilitate private 
sector employers to provide workplace training or internships, and (iii) improve the LMIS. 
 
22. 
TVET  promotion  and  career  guidance.  To  promote  TVET  and  related  career 
opportunities,  the  project  will  undertake  social  marketing  and  outreach  activities  through 
information  materials,  media  campaigns,  and  national  skills  fairs.  The  career  counseling 
services of SEFOPE will be strengthened to assist TVET trainees with job applications and job 
placements.  These  activities  will  be  coordinated  with  employers  and  industry  representatives, 
with special attention to encouraging female participation in nontraditional skills areas. 
 
23.  Workplace  training.  The  project  will  assist  mid-level  skills  training  providers  in 
developing  workplace  training  programs  with  relevant  enterprises.  Contracting  programs  for 
workplace training will be developed with a fixed payment per student to employers to defray the 
costs  of  on-the-job  training.  The  programs  will  pay  special  attention  to  the  placement  of  female 
trainees. The project will also organize workshops to inform and educate private sector employers 
on the role of skills training in improving worker productivity and enterprise profitability. 
 
24. 
Improved  LMIS.  The  existing  LMIS  is  confined  to  gathering  supply-side  information  from 
job-seekers  through  district  employment  centers  and  from  trainees  in  registered  TVET  providers. 
The  project  will  introduce  demand-side  data  through  employer  surveys  and  enterprise  training 
needs  assessments.  Combined  with  supply-side  data,  the  information  will  yield  indicators  of  skills 
shortages  and  training  needs,  which  will  help  SEFOPE  decide  on  funding  allocations  and  assist 
TVET institutions in designing demand-driven training programs. 
 

4. 

Strengthening SEFOPE Financing and Support for Technical and 
Vocational Education and Training  

 
25. 
The project will help SEFOPE strengthen the delivery of mid-level skills training and improve 
its capacity in TVET management. It will support SEFOPE to (i) develop financing plans to sustain 
mid-level  skills  delivery  in  public  and  private  training  institutions;  (ii)  design  strategies  to  expand 
access  to  TVET  by  young  men  and  women,  especially  those  from  poor  and  disadvantaged 
backgrounds; and (iii) expand the implementation of mid-level skills training. 
 
26. 
The  government  is  currently  preparing  a  TVET strategic  plan  which,  once  approved,  will 
assist SEFOPE in expanding mid-level skills training. The project will support the expansion, which 
will  involve  (i)  up-scaling  mid-level  skills  training  with  additional  training  providers  or  programs;  (ii) 
implementing  scholarship  programs  for  mid-level  skills  trainees,  with  a  targeted  allocation  for 
females; and (iii) extending workplace training and placements with employers.  
 

5. 

Project Implementation and Management 

 
27. 
The  project  will  provide  necessary  support  for  the  project  management  unit  (PMU) 
established  in  SEFOPE  to  (i)  establish  the  facilities  and  systems  required  for  effective  project 

5 

 

 6 

 

implementation  and  management;  (ii)  develop  and  implement  a  project  monitoring  and  evaluation 
system  for  main  project  outputs  and  the  gender  action  plan;  and  (iii)  effectively  and  efficiently 
manage  project  activities,  including  procurement,  accounting,  and  regular  reporting  of  project 
progress.  
 
D. 
 
28. 
physical and price contingencies. The project investment plan is summarized in Table 1. 
 

The  project  is  estimated  to  cost  $13  million,  including  taxes  and  duties  of  $159,000,  and

The government has requested a grant of $12 million from ADB’s Special Funds resources 
29. 
to finance 92% of the project cost. The grant will cover civil works, equipment, materials, consulting 
services,  workshops,  vehicles,  project  operations  and  management,  and  taxes  and  duties.14 The 
government will provide in-kind and financial contributions equivalent to $1 million to cover the cost 
of counterpart staff, office space, contingencies, operating costs for additional mid-level trainees at 
Tibar,  and  a  proportion  of  teacher  training  and  national  consultant  costs  essential  for  the 
sustainability of project activities. The financing plan is in Table 2. 
 

Source 
Asian Development Bank (Asian Development Fund grant) 
Government of Timor-Leste 

Table 2: Financing Plan

14 The amount of taxes and duties to be financed (i) is within the threshold identified in the Timor-Leste CPS 2011–2015, (ii) 
does not represent an excessive share of project investment, (iii) applies only to ADB-financed expenditures, and (iv) is 
relevant to the success of the project. Transportation and insurance are also eligible expenses for ADB financing. 

 Implementation Arrangements 

E. 
 
30. 
The executing agency for the project will be SEFOPE. A project steering committee will be 
established,  consisting  of  the  secretary  of  SEFOPE  (chair),  MOE,  members  of  INDMO  executive 
commission, and the Chamber of Commerce and Industry. Key development partners in the TVET 
subsector will participate as observers. The project steering committee will provide overall guidance 
to  the  project  and  ensure  the  integration  of  project  activities  into  overall  TVET  development. 
SEFOPE  will  establish  a  PMU  which  will  be  responsible  for  day-to-day  project  implementation, 
capacity development, planning and budgeting, procurement, disbursement, monitoring, supervising 
implementation at training provider level, and reporting to the government and ADB. The PMU will 
be supported by consultants. 
 
31. 
project administration manual (PAM).15

32. 
For  the  implementation  of  project  activities  in  developing  skills  standards  and  curriculum 
materials (output 1) and teacher training (part of output 2), the International Labor Organization will 
be contracted through single-source selection to ensure the continuity of ongoing efforts to establish 
competency-based skills standards under the NQF. 
 

                                                
15 Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

7 

 

 III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Economic and Financial 

 
A. 
 
The  economic  benefits  of  the  project  result  mainly  from  the  improved  skills  of  trained 
33. 
workers and the higher wages they can earn as skilled compared with unskilled workers. While it is 
reasonable to expect that system-wide improvements in quality and reliability of competency-based 
training  will  benefit  all  students  in  the  TVET  system,  only  the  wage  earnings  of  graduates  from 
project-supported programs are quantified as incremental benefits. Project benefits also include the 
estimated  value  of  increased  activity  in  the  local  economy  that  is  expected  from  higher  worker 
earnings and the greater portion of earnings expended in the local economy. Increased numbers of 
Timorese  workers  (rather  than  foreign  workers)  in  high-paying  jobs  spend  more  in  the  local 
economy  (rather  than  remitting  it  to  home  countries)  and  spur  growth  in  the  local  economy.  The 
economic  analysis  indicates  that  the  project’s  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  will  be 
26.6%. 16  This  high  EIRR  reflects  the  acute  shortage  in  Timor-Leste  of  skilled  workers  in  key 
industries (i.e., construction and transport), which is driven by the country’s rapid growth and rising 
demand for skilled workers. 
 
34. 
The financial analysis assessed the sustainability of the project at national and project levels, 
and evaluated the impact of the proposed investment given current and projected TVET subsector 
funding levels. The analysis concluded that the government has the capacity to absorb and sustain 
the benefits of the project, but that institutional strengthening of SEFOPE is required. Sustainability 
is supported by the existence of the national SDP emphasizing vocational  skills development and 
the ongoing development of a TVET strategic plan. 
 
B. 
 
35. 
Financial management and procurement capacity assessments have been carried out at the 
country  and  executing  agency  levels.  While  the  government  has  made  progress  in  developing 
country-level  financial  management  systems,  further  improvements  are  required,  particularly  in   
budget preparation, execution, accounting, and audit. Procurement regulations have been revised 
several  times  in  recent  years,  and  further  improvements  are  being  made.  This  is  the  first  ADB-
financed project  with SEFOPE. The financial management and procurement capacity of SEFOPE 
was assessed as low. To address this, a PMU will be established within SEFOPE and staffed with 
adequate expertise and consultants to ensure compliance with ADB policies and procedures, and to 
strengthen  the  financial  management  and  procurement  capacity  of  SEFOPE.  All  procurement  will 
follow ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
36. 
ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to  and  discussed 
with the government and SEFOPE. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM (footnote 15). 

Governance 

                                                
16 Details on the calculations of the EIRR estimate are presented in the Economic Analysis (accessible from the list of linked 
documents in Appendix 2). The EIRR is estimated by comparing the expected wages of an unskilled worker over a 10-
year period to the wages of workers with certified skills supported by the project. A survey of wages at automobile repair 
shops  and  construction  firms  around  Dili  conducted  during  project  preparation  augmented  information  on  wages  from 
Timor-Leste Labor Force Survey 2010 (footnote 4) and provided the basis for wages of workers at different skill levels. 

8 

 

 Poverty and Social 

C. 
 
37. 
Despite rapid economic growth and steady progress in human development indicators, the 
poverty  level  remains  high  at  an  estimated  41%  in  2009.17 The  prevalence  of  poverty  is  closely 
associated  with  low  human  resource  levels  in  areas  such  as  literacy,  education,  and  productive 
skills.  The  formal  school  system  does  not  equip  students  with  adequate  knowledge  or  practical 
skills, leaving many young people unemployed while many skilled positions in the rapidly expanding 
infrastructure  construction  are  filled  by  foreign  workers.  The  unemployment  rate  in  urban  areas 
reached  34%  in  2010  for  those  aged  15–24  (footnote  3).  The  project  will  contribute  to  skills 
development for young people by introducing mid-level skills training in construction and automotive 
trades—areas  that  are  in  great  demand  in  the  labor  market—and  enhance  employment  and 
income-earning opportunities.  
 
38. 
Gender. The project is classified as effective gender mainstreaming. To increase women’s 
enrollment  in  nontraditional  skills  training  and  their  employment  in  infrastructure,  a  gender  action 
plan  (GAP)  has  been  prepared.  The  GAP  focuses  on  increasing  female  enrollment  by  (i)  raising 
awareness  of  nontraditional  TVET  and  related  career  options  through  promotional  activities,  (ii) 
making the curriculum more gender sensitive, (iii) providing gender training to TVET management 
and  teaching  staff,  (iv)  constructing  a  dormitory  for  female  trainees  at  Tibar,  (v)  targeting  female 
enrollment of at least 20% in construction and automotive trades by 2016, and (vi) recruiting female 
trainers  in  skills  areas  covered  by  the  project.  The  GAP  aims  to  place  at  least  80%  of  female 
trainees  in  workplace  training  programs  and  strengthen  career  counseling  services  by  involving 
business  women  from  nontraditional  sectors.  The  project  will  also  develop  scholarship  programs 
targeted at females as part of TVET policy implementation plans. 
 
D. 
 
39. 
Environment.  The  project  is  categorized  environment  category  B  and  an  initial 
environmental  examination  was  prepared  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement 
(2009). The initial environmental examination found that environmental impacts are minor and can 
be mitigated. During construction of training and dormitory facilities, excavated materials and solid 
waste  will  be  managed  in  a  manner  that  does  not  create  any  permanent  environmental  impact. 
During operation, the automotive workshop will ensure proper disposal of hazardous waste such as 
engine oil.  
 
40. 
Social  safeguards.  The  project  is  classified  category  C  for  both  involuntary  resettlement 
and  indigenous  peoples  according  to  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  All  civil  works  on 
constructing or upgrading training and dormitory facilities will be undertaken on existing land owned 
by respective institutions within their current boundaries. The project is not expected to involve any 
issues of involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. If any unanticipated issues are identified 
during  implementation,  the  government  will  inform  ADB  and  address  these  issues  according  to 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
E. 
 
41.  Major risks and proposed mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4, and described in 
detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.18   

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

Safeguards 

                                                
17 World  Bank.  2010.  A  2009  Update  of  Poverty  Incidence  in  Timor-Leste  Using  the  Survey-to-Survey  Imputation. 

Washington, DC. 

18 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

9 

 

 10

Weak financial 
management and 
procurement capacity of 
SEFOPE

financially unsustainable 

Poor social perceptions of 
TVET that may limit 
potential trainees’ interest 
in participating in TVET 

Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 

Mitigating Measures 

A PMU will be established within SEFOPE to carry out day-to-day financial 
management and procurement for the project. A financial management and 
procurement specialist, along with consultants for the PMU, will provide 
capacity building training and support to SEFOPE to implement the project. 

SEFOPE’s partnership agreements with training providers will formalize 
their commitments to use their own resources to operate and maintain the 
facilities and equipment provided by the project. SEFOPE’s capacity will be 
strengthened for planning and budgeting, advocating TVET sector 
development, and implementing the TVET strategic plan by mobilizing 
necessary financial resources. 
Social marketing activities will raise awareness in society in general and 
among unemployed youth in particular. Improved quality of training, 
introduction of higher-level skills, workplace training programs, and job 
counseling will help to increase potential trainees’ interest in participating in 
TVET programs. 

Lack of interest among 
private sector employers in 
TVET development 

Private sector employers will be proactively engaged in skills standards and 
curriculum development, workplace training programs, and awareness-
raising activities to ensure a strong linkage between TVET and labor market 
demand. 

Difficulties in increasing 
female enrollment in 
nontraditional skills areas 

SEFOPE will set targets for female enrollment and workplace training in the 
partnership agreement with the training providers, and work closely with 
women’s groups and development partners to promote female participation 
in nontraditional skills areas. 

PMU = project management unit, SEFOPE = Secretariat of State for Vocational Training and Employment, TVET = 
technical and vocational education and training. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 

IV. 

ASSURANCES 

42. 
The government and SEFOPE have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards, gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as  described  in  detail  in 
the PAM  and grant documents. The government  and  SEFOPE  have agreed  with  ADB on certain 
covenants for the project, which are set forth in the grant agreement. Prior to grant effectiveness, the 
government and SEFOPE will have appointed the project director and established the PMU. 
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

43. 
I am satisfied that the proposed grant  would comply  with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the grant not exceeding 
$12,000,000  to  the  Democratic  Republic  of  Timor-Leste  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources  for 
the Mid-Level Skills Training Project, on terms and conditions that are substantially in accordance 
with those set forth in the draft grant agreement presented to the Board. 
 
 

Haruhiko Kuroda 
President 

11 November 2011
